document.masterDocTitle: A review of neococcid scale insects (Hemiptera: Sternorrhyncha: Coccomorpha) based on the morphology of the adult males

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A review of neococcid scale insects (Hemiptera: Sternorrhyncha: Coccomorpha) based on the morphology of the adult males

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined .
USA
, Florida , Mataee Co., Fort De Soto National Memorial, on
Quercus viginiana
( Fagaceae ), 10.i.1977 , Avas Hamon ( USNM ): 2/4 ad â™‚â™‚ (fair-good).

Mounted material : of moderate to small size, total body length 1.20â€“1.23 mm ; antennae slightly more than half body length; body with few setae, fleshy setae (fs) few and sometimes hard to separate from hs; length of fs on antennae about twice width of flagellate antennal segments. Wings longer than total body length.

Head : appearing roundly triangular in dorsal view; width across genae 200â€“215 Âµm . Median crest (mc) poorly demarcated and not apparently reticulated. Preoccipital ridge (por) distinct and sclerotised, bifurcated laterally, posterior ridges slightly longer than anterior ridges; with (on each side) 4â€“6 fs + 6 hs dorsal head setae (dhs); pores absent. Mid-cranial ridge: dorsal ridge (dmcr) possibly absent; ventral ridge (vmcr) distinct and short, extending only about half-way to preocular ridge; lateral arms (lmcr) well developed; area ventral/posterior to vmcr not reticulated, broadest posteriorly, with 5â€“7 fs + 3â€“5 hs ventral mid-cranial ridge setae (vmcrs) on each side. Genae (g) not reticulated and without genal setae (gs). Eyes: with five pairs of round simple eyes: a large dorsal pair (dse) placed rather laterally, each 45â€“50 Âµm wide; 3 pairs of small lateral eyes, each 28â€“33 Âµm wide, in a line extending ventrally to larger ventral eyes (vse), each 45â€“47 Âµm wide. Ocelli (o) obvious; just about touching postocular ridge (pocr) posteriorly. Ocular sclerite (ocs) sclerotised and indistinctly polygonally reticulated. Preocular ridge (procr) very short dorsally, but extending ventrally to just mesad of each ventral eye. Postocular ridge (pocr) strongly developed, extending dorsally past posterior margin of each dorsal eye, not nearly reaching preoccipital ridge (por) medially. Dorsal ocular setae (docs) absent. Ventral head setae (vhs): none anterior to ventral eyes but with 2 or 3 setae between ventral eyes. Preoral ridge (pror) quite well developed. Cranial apophysis (ca) quite short and trifid but occasionally appearing bifid; length 33â€“35 Âµm .

Antennae : 10-segmented and filiform; 725â€“750 Âµm long (ratio of total body length to antennal length 1:0.6). Scape (scp): 30â€“33 Âµm long, 46 Âµm wide, with 3 hs. Pedicel (pdc): length 58â€“63 Âµm , width 33â€“35 Âµm ; with a few concentric ridges across whole width of segment; with 12 or 13 fs + 2â€“4 hs. Segments IIIâ€“X all 20â€“28 Âµm wide: fs 35â€“50 Âµm long; lengths of segments (Âµm): III 138â€“142; IV 105â€“111; V 90â€“92; VI 90â€“92; VII 63â€“75; VIII 54â€“60 and IX 40â€“55; approximate number of setae per segment: IIIâ€“VI each with 16â€“19 fs + 1 or 2 hs; VII 11â€“15 fs + 0 or 1 hs; VIII 10 or 11 fs, 0 or 1 hs + 1 bristle (ab); IX 12â€“14 fs, 0 or 1 hs + 1 ab. Segment X elongate oval, length 45â€“52 Î¼m; not constricted apically; with 4 capitate setae (caps), 4â€“8 fs, 0 hs, 3 large + probably 2 small ab + 1 sensilla basiconica (sb) near apex.

Thorax . Prothorax : pronotal ridge (prnr) well-developed but probably not fused dorsally; with a well-developed, striated, lateral pronotal sclerite (prn), without lateral pronotal (lpns) setae. Medial pronotal and post-tergital setae apparently absent. Post-tergites not detected. Sternum with a narrow transverse ridge, each with an apophysis; median ridge quite long and narrow, with 1 fs prosternal setae (stn 1 s) on each side. Anteprosternal (astn 1 s) and antemesospiracular setae (am 2 s) absent.

Mesothorax : prescutum (prsc) wider than long, 78â€“87 Âµm long; 149â€“158 Âµm wide; sclerotised but not reticulated; with 1â€“4 pairs of small setae on outer margins; prescutal ridges (pscr) and prescutal suture (pscs) well developed. Scutum (sct): median membranous area quite large and quadrate, 70â€“75 Âµm long, 153â€“158 Âµm wide, with sclerotised ridges along lateral margins, without setae; lateral margins of scutum sclerotised but not apparently reticulated; with 1 scutal seta (scts) on each side laterad to membranous area; prealare ridge (prar) quite well developed. Scutellum (scl) 168â€“183 Âµm wide and 78â€“83 Âµm long; with an inverted U-shaped scutellar ridge (sclr); probably not tubular but with a large foramen; with 1 pair of small setae (scls) but no small pores. Basisternum (stn 2 ) 250â€“280 Âµm wide, 135â€“165 Âµm long; without any signs of a median ridge (mdr), but bounded anteriorly by a strong marginal ridge (mr) and posteriorly by strong precoxal ridges (pcr 2 ); basisternal setae (stn 2 s) absent; lateropleurite (lpl) quite broad, with a strong extension from marginal ridge along anterior margin; furca (f) well developed, narrow-waisted, arms very divergent and extending just anterior to point where marginal and precoxal ridges meet. Mesopostnotum (pn 2 ) and postnotal apophysis (pna) well developed. Area bounded anteriorly by scutellum and laterally and posteriorly by mesopostnotum membranous. Mesepisternum (eps 2 ) not reticulated; subepisternal ridge (ser) long and well developed. Postalare (pa) with radial ridges dorsally near posterior notal wing process; without postalare setae (pas). Mesothoracic spiracle (sp 2 ): width of peritreme 32â€“35 Âµm . Postmesospiracular setae (pm 2 s) absent. Tegula (teg) present, with 3 or 4 hs tegular setae (tegs) on each side.

Metathorax : metatergal setae (mts) and dorsospiracular setae (dss) absent. Metapostnotal sclerite indistinct. Dorsal part of metapleural ridge (plr 3 ) well developed, with an indistinct suspensorial sclerite (ss). Ventral part of metapleural ridge well developed; precoxal ridge (pcr 3 ) broad and sclerotised but not apparently fused with metapleural ridge; metepisternum (eps 3 ) membranous, with 0â€“4 hs postmetaspiracular setae (eps 3 s) on either side near precoxal ridge. Metepimeron (epm 3 ) sclerotised, but without setae. Antemetaspiracular setae (am 3 s) absent. Metathoracic spiracle (sp 3 ): width of peritreme 30â€“33 Âµm . Metasternum (stn 3 ) lightly sclerotised, with distinct metasternal apophyses (st 3 a); with 9â€“17 fs anterior metasternal setae (amss) and 7â€“15 fs posterior metasternal setae (pmss).

Wings : hyaline, quite broad,
1250â€“1325 Âµm
long and 550â€“565 Âµm wide (ratio of length to width 1:0.43; ratio of total body length to wing length 1:1.06); alar lobe (al) distinct; without alar setae (als). Hamulohalteres each 100â€“105 Âµm long, 22â€“25 Âµm wide; each with a single hooked hamulus, 60â€“64 Âµm long.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 62.
Allokermes galliformis (Riley)
. Macropterous male. ( Kermesidae ). Where A=cranial apophysis.

subSubSection.paragraph: Legs : prothoracic legs perhaps marginally longest. Coxae (cx): I 90â€“100; II 90â€“95; III 83â€“85 Âµm long; coxa

III with 9â€“12 fs + 6â€“8 hs. Trochanter (tr) + femur (fm): I 230â€“245; II 218â€“222; III 225â€“228 Âµm long; trochanter III with about 6 fs + 2 or 3 hs; long trochanter seta undifferentiated but seta in this position about 40 Âµm long; femur III with 26â€“33 fs + 19â€“21 hs. Tibia (ti): I 230â€“253; II 200â€“230; III 235â€“245 Âµm ; tibia III with 41â€“45 fs + 17â€“20 hs but many becoming spur-like on distal third; with 2 apical spurs (tibs), length 21â€“33 Âµm . Tarsi (ta): I 102â€“108; II 90â€“110; III 97â€“100 Âµm long (ratio of length of tibia III to tarsus III 1:0.41); tarsus III with 10â€“19 fs + 5â€“10 hs but many setae spur-like; tarsal spurs not differentiated; tarsal campaniform pore present; tarsal digitules (tdt) slightly shorter than claw. Claws (c) robust, distinctly longer than width of tarsi ( 16â€“18 Âµm ), slightly curved, with a distinct small denticle at apex; length: III 26â€“28 Âµm ; claw digitules (cdt) slightly longer than claw, capitate and very thin.

Abdomen : segments Iâ€“VII: tergites (at) and sternites (as) not apparently sclerotised. Caudal extension (ce) of segment VII absent. Dorsal abdominal setae (ads): segments Iâ€“VII each with 1 pair hs; ventral abdominal setae (avs) (totals): II 6â€“16 fs +4 or 5 hs; IIIâ€“V each with 7â€“14 fs + 4 or 5 hs; VI & VII each with 3â€“7 fs + 2 or 4 hs. Pleural setae: dorsopleural setae (dps) (on each side): Iâ€“VI each with 2â€“4 fs + 1 hs; Vâ€“VII each with 4 fs + 1 hs; ventropleural setae (vps) I 0 or 1 hs; IIIâ€“VII each with 1 fs + 1 hs.

Segment VIII: sternite (as) clearly sclerotised; tergite apparently unsclerotised; latter with 2 pairs of long hs dorsal abdominal setae; sternite with 2â€“5 hs ventral abdominal setae (avs); caudal extensions (ce) rounded, each with 1 very long seta, 75â€“80 Âµm long + 2 short hs dorsal pleural setae + 1 or 2 hs ventral pleural setae. Glandular pouches (gp) present, deep, pores restricted to within each pouch; glandular pouch setae each 128â€“133 Âµm long.

Genital segments : segment IX sclerotised, broad, 95â€“100 Âµm wide, 75â€“80 Âµm long; anal opening present medially on anterior border; with 2 or 3 hs on postero-dorsal surface and about 7 ventrally. Style quite broad anteriorly ( 40â€“50 Âµm wide), tapering to a blunt point; sclerotised; length from base of style 85â€“90 Âµm long; total length of penial sheath 160â€“165 Âµm (ratio of total body length to length of penial sheath 1:0.13); style with a few very short setae (pss) anteriorly and a few small sensilla (psp) near apex. Aedeagus (aed) elongate, narrowing to a blunt point, length about 100 Âµm ; basal rod (bra) length about 52 Âµm .

Comment. Recently,
Krutil et al. (2019)
also redescribed the adult male of
A. galliformis
. However, their interpretation of the structure is rather different to that given above. In particular, their description of the thorax makes no mention of the membranous area medially on the dorsum of the scutum (even though it is clearly shown in their Fig.10 !), a particularly important feature. There are a number of other significant misinterpretations of the structure of other parts of the thorax as well. In addition, they also considered that the dorsal and ventral simple eyes had a granular structure but their photomicrograph of a dorsal simple eyes (their Fig. 6 ) clearly shows that the granulations are also present on structures next to the simple eye, suggesting that the granulations are an aberration introduced during mounting. However, their photomicrographs of the head (their Figs 3-5 ) clearly suggest that polygonal reticulation might be more widespread than noted here, with reticulation present on the dorsal mid-cranial ridge and also on the genae.
